perforator_anatomy.clinical_significance: Paratibial perforators most commonly associated with ulceration

duplex_criteria: Location beneath or near skin changes/ulcers
diagnosis.technique: Augmentation by distal compression or proximal release
diagnosis.mapping: Mark location with skin marker prior to procedure

surgical_seps.approach: Endoscopic camera and instruments in subfascial plane

presentation: Palpable fascial defect with varicose cluster
treatment: First address superficial and deep reflux
Select treatment based on size, location, and expertise

definition.@value: Therapeutic interventions to eliminate incompetent perforating veins contributing to venous hypertension, including percutaneous ablation techniques and subfascial endoscopic surgery, with patient selection based on perforator characteristics and clinical severity.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define pathologic perforating veins by duplex criteria
Identify common perforator locations and their clinical significance
Compare percutaneous ablation and SEPS for perforator treatment
Apply treatment algorithms for incompetent perforators
clinical_pearls: Pathologic perforator: >3.5mm, >0.5sec outward flow, symptomatic location
Always treat superficial reflux before isolated perforator intervention
Paratibial (Cockett) perforators are most commonly associated with ulcers
PAPS has largely replaced SEPS due to equivalent efficacy and less morbidity
Mark perforator location on skin before procedure - they're hard to find from inside!

medicalCode.description: Vascular endoscopy, surgical, with ligation of perforator veins
